text: Complete atelectasis of the left upper lobe.
74 mm mass with poor contrast enhancement, obstructing the left upper lobe bronchus, considered to be lung cancer.
Enlargement of the left pulmonary hilum and ipsilateral mediastinal lymph nodes, suggesting lymph node metastases.
Enlarged lymph nodes on the right side of the trachea, also suspected to be lymph node metastases.
The left lower lobe bronchus is also infiltrated by the tumor and is narrowed.
No pleural effusion.
Normal appearance of the visualized upper abdomen.
Tumorous lesion with a diameter of 30 mm in the right lower lobe, S8.
Its margin is spiculated.
There is a possibility of lung cancer, so thorough examination in pulmonary medicine is recommended.
Cord-like opacity in the left lower lobe, similar to an inflammatory scar.
Enlargement of a right hilar lymph node is suspected.
No pleural effusion.
Pulmonary mass with a diameter of 5 cm in the right lung apex with spiculated margins, suspicious of lung cancer.

No mediastinal or hilar lymph node enlargement.
No pleural effusion.
The left adrenal gland is enlarged, likely an adenoma.
No significant findings in other abdominal organs.
Tumorous lesion with a maximum diameter of 72 mm in the left lower lobe, suspicious of lung cancer.

Associated obstructive pneumonia in the left lower lobe.
The left hilum and ipsilateral mediastinal lymph nodes are enlarged, suspicious of lymph node metastases.
The left axillary lymph nodes are enlarged, suspicious of lymph node metastases.
Small amount of pleural effusion on the left.
Osteolytic lesions in the proximal end of the left humerus and the left scapula, suspicious of bone metastases.
Cystic lesion in the midline skin of the back, possibly a sebaceous cyst.
Prominent emphysematous changes.
Irregular lobulated mass with a maximum diameter of 47 mm in the left upper lobe, with noticeable spiculated margins and pleural indentation.
This correlates to a known lung cancer with pleural invasion.

No other pathological lymph node enlargement.
No pleural effusion.

Enlargement of the left hilar lymph nodes, suspicious of metastasis.
No lymph node metastasis in the mediastinum or on the opposite side, considered as N1.
No pleural effusion.

No significant findings in the gallbladder, pancreas, or spleen.

No pleural effusion.
A hypovascular lesion is observed in the liver S5, which appears to be continuous with the gallbladder, suspicious of metastasis, or possibly gallbladder cancer.
